channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Science 'Gone Wrong' Can Teach Us
item.description: August 25, 2017 - Pandora's Lab stresses that for science to work, it needs to base claims on data, studies need to be replicable, and scientists must be more attached to science than to their own ideas, says Alva Noë.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 25, 2017 - Pandora's Lab stresses that for science to work, it needs to base claims on data, studies need to be replicable, and scientists must be more attached to science than to their own ideas, says Alva Noë. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/08/25/545508337/science-gone-wrong-can-teach-us

item.title: Moshe Szyf: How Do Our Experiences Rewire Our Brains And Bodies?
item.description: August 25, 2017 - Many think genetic makeup is fixed from the moment we're born. But Moshe Szyf says this understanding is incomplete because our experiences and environment have the power to change our basic biology.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 25, 2017 - Many think genetic makeup is fixed from the moment we're born. But Moshe Szyf says this understanding is incomplete because our experiences and environment have the power to change our basic biology. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/25/545092951/moshe-szyf-how-do-our-experiences-rewire-our-brains-and-bodies

item.title: Brian Little: Are Human Personalities Hardwired?
item.description: August 25, 2017 - Are you introverted or extroverted? It depends. When it comes to personality, psychologist Brian Little says we can actually act against our biology — especially if we pursue a "core life project."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 25, 2017 - Are you introverted or extroverted? It depends. When it comes to personality, psychologist Brian Little says we can actually act against our biology — especially if we pursue a "core life project." http://www.npr.org/2017/08/25/545093051/brian-little-are-human-personalities-hardwired

item.title: Nadine Burke Harris: How Does Trauma Affect A Child's DNA?
item.description: August 25, 2017 - Pediatrician Nadine Burke Harris found an unsettling trend when examining patients at her clinic: trauma. She found that adversity can change a child's biology and result in severe health outcomes.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 25, 2017 - Pediatrician Nadine Burke Harris found an unsettling trend when examining patients at her clinic: trauma. She found that adversity can change a child's biology and result in severe health outcomes. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/25/545092982/nadine-burke-harris-how-does-trauma-affect-a-childs-dna

item.title: Robert Sapolsky: How Much Agency Do We Have Over Our Behavior?
item.description: August 25, 2017 - Neuroscientist Robert Sapolsky says nearly all aspects of human behavior are explained by biology: from developments millions of years in the past to microscopic reactions happening in the present.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 25, 2017 - Neuroscientist Robert Sapolsky says nearly all aspects of human behavior are explained by biology: from developments millions of years in the past to microscopic reactions happening in the present. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/25/545092668/robert-sapolsky-how-much-agency-do-we-have-over-our-behavior

item.title: After A Suicide, Sibling Survivors Are Often Overlooked
item.description: August 25, 2017 - Recent studies show that people who survive a brother or sister's suicide are at great risk of mood disorders and mental health problems, including thoughts of harming themselves.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 25, 2017 - Recent studies show that people who survive a brother or sister's suicide are at great risk of mood disorders and mental health problems, including thoughts of harming themselves. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/25/545554065/after-a-suicide-sibling-survivors-are-often-overlooked

item.title: 25 Years Later: How Hurricane Andrew Impacted Emergency Response
item.description: August 24, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with former FEMA Administrator Craig Fugate about the important changes inspired by the historic Category 5 storm, in computer modeling, housing codes and insurance.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 24, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with former FEMA Administrator Craig Fugate about the important changes inspired by the historic Category 5 storm, in computer modeling, housing codes and insurance. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/24/545901808/25-years-later-hurricane-andrews-devastation-lingers

item.title: Texas Coast Prepares For Strengthened Hurricane Harvey
item.description: August 24, 2017 - The National Hurricane Center now says Harvey will be a major hurricane when it arrives in Texas late Friday. The overnight escalation surprised planners who were told it would be a tropical storm.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 24, 2017 - The National Hurricane Center now says Harvey will be a major hurricane when it arrives in Texas late Friday. The overnight escalation surprised planners who were told it would be a tropical storm. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/24/545901801/texas-coast-prepares-for-strengthened-hurricane-harvey

item.title: Really? Really. How Our Brains Figure Out What Words Mean Based On How They're Said
item.description: August 24, 2017 - Scientists have identified the brain cells that detect pitch changes in speech, allowing us to understand whether someone is asking a question or making a statement.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 24, 2017 - Scientists have identified the brain cells that detect pitch changes in speech, allowing us to understand whether someone is asking a question or making a statement. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/24/545711940/pitch-neurons

item.title: Washington Declares Open Season On Escaped Aquaculture Salmon
item.description: August 23, 2017 - State wildlife officials have asked the public to catch as many of the non-native Atlantic salmon as they can after an estimated 5,000 escaped from an aquaculture farm.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 23, 2017 - State wildlife officials have asked the public to catch as many of the non-native Atlantic salmon as they can after an estimated 5,000 escaped from an aquaculture farm. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/23/545550187/washington-declares-open-season-on-escaped-aquaculture-salmon

item.title: To Infinity And Beyond: Celebrating 40 Years Of The Voyager Mission
item.description: August 23, 2017 - The Farthest: Voyager In Space, airing Wednesday on PBS, celebrates a technological and intellectual achievement rarely matched in history — one that has forever changed us, says Marcelo Gleiser.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 23, 2017 - The Farthest: Voyager In Space, airing Wednesday on PBS, celebrates a technological and intellectual achievement rarely matched in history — one that has forever changed us, says Marcelo Gleiser. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/08/23/545484098/to-infinity-and-beyond-celebrating-40-years-of-the-voyager-mission

item.title: Los Angeles Tests Whether Lighter Color Streets Will Lower The Temperature
item.description: August 23, 2017 - Los Angeles is piloting a project called "Cool Pavement." The city is putting a light grey coating on top of some neighborhood streets in an effort to lower the air temperature.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 23, 2017 - Los Angeles is piloting a project called "Cool Pavement." The city is putting a light grey coating on top of some neighborhood streets in an effort to lower the air temperature. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/23/545435062/los-angeles-tests-whether-lighter-color-streets-will-lower-the-temperature

item.title: The Battle Over Oil And Gas Development In Colorado
item.description: August 23, 2017 - A deadly home explosion in Colorado is renewing fights over how close oil and gas development should be to expanding suburbs. One town is trying to figure out for itself how close is too close.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 23, 2017 - A deadly home explosion in Colorado is renewing fights over how close oil and gas development should be to expanding suburbs. One town is trying to figure out for itself how close is too close. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/23/545435045/the-battle-over-oil-and-gas-development-in-colorado

item.title: Dakota Access Pipeline Owner Sues Greenpeace For 'Criminal Activity'
item.description: August 22, 2017 - Energy Transfer Partners alleges Greenpeace and other "eco-terrorist groups" tried to block its pipeline with "campaigns of misinformation." Greenpeace says the suit is a bid to "silence free speech."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 22, 2017 - Energy Transfer Partners alleges Greenpeace and other "eco-terrorist groups" tried to block its pipeline with "campaigns of misinformation." Greenpeace says the suit is a bid to "silence free speech." http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/22/545310247/dakota-access-pipeline-owner-sues-greenpeace-for-criminal-activity

item.title: Scientists Hope To Farm The Biofuel Of The Future In The Pacific Ocean
item.description: August 22, 2017 - International research labs are using seaweed to make biofuel, but little progress has been made in the U.S. Now scientists in California are developing a prototype to enable vast open-ocean farming.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 22, 2017 - International research labs are using seaweed to make biofuel, but little progress has been made in the U.S. Now scientists in California are developing a prototype to enable vast open-ocean farming. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/08/22/542903378/scientists-hope-to-farm-the-biofuel-of-the-future-in-the-pacific-ocean
